Description: Legendary prophet and bard also known as Merlin.
Name for Britain or Brittany, derived from Celtic word meaning 'painted' or 'tattooed.'
Mythical founder of Britain, descendant of Aeneas and a Trojan exile.
Legendary king of Britain, son of Belinus, and conqueror of Denmark.
Historical king of Britain who fought against Julius Caesar's invasion.
Name of several historical and legendary kings of Britain or Brittany.
Legendary king of Britain, father of King Arthur, and son of Constantine III.
Famous legendary king of Britain, known for leading Britons against the Saxons.
Historical king of Gwynedd (Wales), descendant of King Arthur, and leader against Anglo-Saxons.
Name of various historical and legendary kings or princes of Brittany or Cornwall.
Historical king of Strathclyde (Scotland) and leader against Anglo-Saxons.
6th-century British monk and historian who wrote about the Roman withdrawal and Saxon invasions.
7th-8th-century Anglo-Saxon monk and scholar known for writing about the conversion of England to Christianity.
9th-century British writer traditionally credited with the authorship of the Historia Brittonum.
Name of Geoffrey of Monmouth, a 12th-century British cleric famous for his Historia Regum Britanniae.
Name of Gerald of Wales, a 12th-century Welsh cleric known for works on Wales and Ireland.
Name of Alan of Lille, a 12th-century French theologian and poet.
Name of Henry II, a 12th-century king of England.
Name of Richard I, a 12th-13th-century king of England.
Name of John I, a 13th-century king of England.
Name of Alexander III, a 13th-century king of Scotland.
Name of Edward I, a 13th-14th-century king of England.
Name of Robert I, a 14th-century king of Scotland.
Name of David II, a 14th-century king of Scotland.
Name of Edward III, a 14th-century king of England.
Name of Richard II, a 14th-15th-century king of England.
Name of Henry IV, a 15th-century king of England.
Name of Henry V, a 15th-century king of England.
